data.body: Rishi Madhuchchhandah Vaishvamitrah's Mantra on Agni recited in Gayatri Chhand meter.
प्रथमं मण्डलमं, अनु १, प्रथमं सूक्तम् ऋषि मधुच्छन्दा वैश्वामित्रः छन्द: गायत्री अग्निः देव
उप तवाग्ने दिवे-दिवे दोषावस्तर्धिया वयम । नमो भरन्त एमसि ॥
upa tva-agney divey-a-divey dosa-a-vasta-r-dhiya vayam; namo bharanta yamasi
Agni, everyday, at night and in daylight (1), we approach you (3), carrying our obeisance (nama) by our thought (dhiya) (2).

upa (near) tva agney (you and I, agni) divey-a-divey (day by day) dosa-a-vasta (night and in light) dhiya (in thought and intelligence) vayam (we) namah (pay homage) bharanta (carry) aa imasi (we come to)

The means to get Agni is through spiritual practice which is rooted in meditation;  meditation that works under all conditions, whether in light or in dark. There is no ritual or rite mentioned, indicating the esoteric nature of the yajna. The adoration of Agni and the constant meditation on him, while engaged in all activities, is the definitive sign of contact with Agni. *dhiya*: plural of dhi, meaning thought, understanding or intelligence. This corresponds to the later word *buddhi*. It is given a variety of meanings like, *water, work, sacrifice, food, and thought* by Sayanacharya. But its natural interpretation given here fits in all the verses of Veda where it occurs. *nama*: obeisance or a spirit of self-surrender. It is not a physical act, but a thought. Sayanacharya mostly translates as *food*. It occurs more than 250 times in the Rig Veda. *upa + emasi*: we approach.
